edge: Bajirao I was a renowned Maratha Peshwa during the 18th century.
The film Bajirao Mastani is based on the story of the Maratha Peshwa Bajirao I and his second wife, Mastani.
Ranveer Singh portrays the role of Bajirao I in the film Bajirao Mastani.
Deepika Padukone plays the role of Mastani, who was the second wife of Bajirao I.

The court of Maratha Chhatrapati Shahu needed a new Peshwa in 1720, and Ambaji Pant Purandare nominated Bajirao. This indicates that Bajirao was a significant figure in Shahu's court.
Bajirao received the Peshwa title after successfully splitting a peacock feather with an arrow, as requested by the court of Maratha Chhatrapati Shahu.
Kashibai was married to Bajirao, indicating a close relationship between the two characters.
Bhanu's husband was accused of spying and ordered to be executed by Bajirao. This indicates that Bajirao had authority over executing accusations.
Kashibai's friend Bhanu visited her and predicted that she would yearn for Bajirao just as Bhanu yearned for her husband.
Bajirao Mastani was praised and received numerous accolades, including 7 National Film Awards and 14 nominations at the 61st Filmfare Awards.
Bajirao Mastani grossed over ₹356.2 crore at the box office, making it one of the highest grossing Hindi films of 2015.
Bajirao Mastani was praised for Bhansali's direction, indicating his significant contribution to the film.
Bajirao Mastani was noted for its attention to detail, indicating a focus on intricate aspects of the film.

While travelling to Sironja, an emissary from Bundelkhand requests Bajirao's help to fight invaders. She reveals herself to be Mastani, the daughter of the Hindu Rajput king Chhatrasal and his Persian Shia concubine Ruhani Begum. Impressed by her skills as a warrior, Bajirao assists her with his army and defeats the invaders.
She reveals herself to be Mastani, the daughter of the Hindu Rajput king Chhatrasal and his Persian Shia concubine Ruhani Begum.

Back home in Pune, Kashibai greets Bajirao with a tour of their newly built Shaniwar Wada and the Aaina Mahal (Hall of Mirrors), which allows her to see him from her room. Mastani arrives in Pune but is treated harshly by Bajirao's mother Radhabai and accommodated in the palace for dancers, as Radhabai refuses to accept her as a daughter-in-law.
Radhabai refuses to accept her as a daughter-in-law.

Determined to pursue her love, Mastani arrives in Pune but is treated harshly by Bajirao's mother Radhabai and accommodated in the palace for dancers, as Radhabai refuses to accept her as a daughter-in-law. Mastani tolerates this and adamantly expresses her desire to be with Bajirao; Bajirao chides in her persistence, reminding her he is already married and will never fully be hers; his court will also never respect her. Mastani agrees to these conditions so Bajirao declares her his second wife.
Preparation for attacking Delhi required ensuring Nizam's neutrality, which Bajirao achieved through a successful confrontation with the Nizam.
Kashibai witnessed Bajirao's affection for Mastani, leading to her heartbreak and departure. They later reunited after the birth of their respective sons.
Raghunath was born to Kashibai and named by her after she left following seeing Bajirao with Mastani.
Bajirao renamed his son Shamsher Bahadur after a Brahmin priest refused to conduct the Hindu naming ceremony due to Krishna Rao's illegitimacy.
Nana Saheb expressed his hatred towards Mastani for breaking his mother's marriage due to her relationship with Bajirao.

plan to murder Mastani and her son during the Ganesh Chaturthi festival, rescue of Mastani by Bajirao, building of a palace for Mastani by Bajirao, imprisonment of Mastani and her son by Bajirao's mother and Nana Saheb

leaving for the battlefield to defeat Nasir Jung, meeting Kashibai in deference to tradition before leaving, breaking Kashibai's heart and taking her pride, compares their love with that of Krishna and Rukmini, asking Bajirao never to enter her chamber again, teary-eyed acceptance by Bajirao

Sanjay Leela Bhansali had conceived a historical romance about Maratha Peshwa Bajirao and his second wife Mastani even before he had directed his first feature Khamoshi: The Musical in 1996. Reports about a possible revival of the film had made headlines ever since, but the project was shelved indefinitely. Bhansali had planned to revive it every other year but the project never came to fruition due to the destiny of every film having its own fate. However, the souls of Bajirao, Mastani, and Kashibai wanted them to make this film only now.
Several other directors such as Muzaffar Ali had tried to make a film about the two historical figures but they were never made.
Several other directors such as Manmohan Desai had tried to make a film about the two historical figures but they were never made.
Several other directors such as Kamal Amrohi had tried to make a film about the two historical figures but they were never made.
Bhansali had intended to make Bajirao Mastani after finishing every film he made in-between, including Devdas.
Bhansali had officially announced Bajirao Mastani in 2003, with filming scheduled to begin in May 2004.

The project faced numerous setbacks and delays over a period of eleven years, leading some in the film industry to believe it would never be made. This has led to the label 'jinxed' being associated with the film.
Despite facing setbacks and delays, Bhansali remained steadfast in his determination to make the film. His persistence and focus have been described as resilient.
Despite considering the project impossible to make, Bhansali clung to his ambition to make Bajirao Mastani. His unwavering commitment to the project is a testament to the power of ambition.
In pursuing Bajirao Mastani, Bhansali displayed remarkable focus and dedication. His single-mindedness has been a defining characteristic of the project.

In speaking about his desire to make Bajirao Mastani, Bhansali said, 'When you dream very genuinely, then I believe you also get the power to fulfill it.' This highlights the importance of resilience in realizing one's dreams.
Bhansali's statement, 'I want very few things in life...so I know that I am resilient enough to get them all!' demonstrates his focused and determined mindset.
Bhansali's belief that the script for Bajirao Mastani was so powerful he had to make it one day is a testament to the importance of a compelling narrative in realizing a project.
The film Bajirao Mastani was reportedly an adaptation of the Marathi-language novel Rau (1976) by Nagnath S. Inamdar.

In speaking about his desire to make Bajirao Mastani, Bhansali said, 'Deep down, I kept asking for the universe to let me make this film.' This highlights the importance of belief and faith in realizing one's dreams.
In pursuing Bajirao Mastani, Bhansali sacrificed many things, demonstrating his focused and dedicated mindset.

Their relationship was rarely depicted in history books and little was known about it due to the fact that they defied everything to be in love with each other, which is a comment on religion and love. This relationship between a Hindu man and a Muslim woman challenged societal norms during those times, as it does today. Bhansali saw this as an opportunity to shed light on the timelessness of these issues.
Wrote the screenplay for 'Padmaavat' based on the novel.

The pre-production work for the film lasted nineteen months and continued as the shoot progressed.

node_2: saloni dhatrak, sriram iyengar and sujeet sawant
edge: Iyengar and Sawant had heard about the film while working on another film, when it was first announced. Having never met Bhansali, they started researching on their own by visiting Pune and Satara and learnt about Maratha architecture.

When the film was shelved, they continued to research and formed a portfolio, hoping to approach other filmmakers for work. Several years later, when they heard about the revival, they met Bhansali, who was impressed by their research and presentation.

node_2: saloni dhatrak, sriram iyengar and sujeet sawant
edge: During pre-production work, Saloni Dhatrak, Sriram Iyengar and Sujeet Sawant discussed with Bhansali about how much of the film would be filmed on set and outdoor locations, giving them an idea to how many sets they needed to create.

node_2: considering its scale, the film required detailed and extravagant pre-production work, which required extensive research and planning.
edge: Saloni Dhatrak, Sriram Iyengar and Sujeet Sawant worked as production designers on the film.
Shaniwar Wada set, one of the biggest sets constructed in Film City, took forty-five days to build and required 45,000 planks and 600 workers a day.
along with art directors, nineteen art assistant directors including architects were involved in creating twenty-two sets for the production.

architectural research from Pune, Nasik and Satara was done to understand the interior and exterior designs of the ancient period and incorporated those ideas into building Kashibai's villa. Lotus motifs on mud-clad walls and handmade textures were used to give the Shaniwar Wada set a realistic appearance.
Kashibai's room was the first set to be constructed and required navigating through twenty-five designs before being approved.

Aina Mahal, a set in the movie, took inspiration from the Mughal concept of mirror halls. The replica of Aina Mahal constructed for the movie followed the Mughal design of walls, ceiling and floor made out of handmade mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs.

The art directors designed Mastani Mahal, the set in the movie, to look like Maratha architecture but retained the Mughal concept of mirror halls. The interiors of Mastani's room in Bundelkhand, crafted using a mix of Persian, Mughal and Rajput motifs and architecture, also followed the Mughal design of walls, ceiling and floor made out of handmade mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs.

Aina Mahal took 4,500 planks and more than 30,00 square feet of mirrors to construct its mirror halls. The set's lotus-like design with walls, ceiling and floor made out of handmade mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs is a feature of these halls.
Mastani Mahal, the set in the movie, also had mirror halls, with a mix of Persian, Mughal and Rajput motifs and architecture. The hall's design was decorated using more than 700 design stencils.

The walls, ceiling and floor of the Aina Mahal set were made out of handmade mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs. This traditional Mughal design technique was used for both Aina Mahal and Mastani Mahal.

The interior of Mastani's room in Bundelkhand, crafted using a mix of Persian, Mughal and Rajput motifs and architecture, also used the traditional Mughal design technique of handmade mud embedded with sparkling mirror designs.
The walls, ceiling and floor of the Aina Mahal set were embellished with sparkling mirror designs. This traditional Mughal design technique was used for both Aina Mahal and Mastani Mahal.

The interior of Mastani's room in Bundelkhand, crafted using a mix of Persian, Mughal and Rajput motifs and architecture, also used the traditional Mughal design technique of sparkling mirror designs.
Aina Mahal was a set constructed for the movie. It took 4,500 planks and more than 30,00 square feet of mirrors to construct its mirror halls.
Mastani Mahal was also a set constructed for the movie. Its interior, including Mastani's room in Bundelkhand, had mirror halls decorated using more than 700 design stencils.
The construction of Aina Mahal required a hundred workers per day.
Mastani Mahal's exterior was built as a part of Shaniwar Wada. The interiors of Mastani Mahal were constructed on separate sets consisting of a courtyard and bedroom.

The movie required approximately 300 costumes, specifically for the three main characters.
To create authentic costumes, real zari (thin metallic wire used for embroidery) and gold wires were incorporated into the designs.

node_2: references for designing her looks and costumes
edge: Since no visual reference could be found for Kashibai, the paintings of Raja Ravi Varma were utilized as a basis for creating her appearance and attire.
For Chopra, Modi created eighty nauvari (nine-yard saris) in vibrant colors like yellow, hot pink, emerald green, and purple that were inspired by the Raja Ravi Varma paintings.

The custom-made nauvari (nine-yard saris) worn in that period were crafted by artisans from Maheshwar, Chander, and Varanasi. They were designed to be lighter than usual to prevent Chopra from appearing overweight on screen.
For the saris worn during that period, fabrics like silk, muslin, khadi, and chanderi were employed in their design.

For Mastani, Nizami and polki jewellery were used.

Principal photography began on 9 October 2014 with Cinematographer Sudeep Chatterjee on the set in Film City, Mumbai.

Deepika Padukone joined the cast for two days during late December 2014 and resumed shooting in April 2015 after completing work for her other projects. Cinematographer Sudeep Chatterjee was involved in the shoot.
Outdoor location filming began in February 2015 at Amer Fort in Jaipur.
Singh fell off a horse while filming an action sequence and was rushed to hospital; he was not seriously injured.
In May 2015, however, he injured his shoulder and needed surgery; he resumed shooting after break of two months.

Before starting the film, the team discussed which parts of it had to be filmed and which parts needed to be made using visual effects. They decided that only sequences that were considered difficult or impossible to film would be created using visual effects in post production. In one sequence, it was impossible to control the movements of the 300–400 horses standing at one position in a battle scene; this sequence was filmed with a small number of horses and was later enhanced in post production.

One sequence required the movements of 300–400 horses standing at one position to be controlled, which was considered impossible. This sequence was filmed with a small number of horses and was later enhanced in post production.

R. M. Vijayakar of India-West gave the album 4.5 out of 5, calling it "unforgettable" and complimented the use of musical instruments and orchestration, noting portions of the score as the most significant standout.

Joginder Tuteja of Bollywood Hungama gave a rating of 3.5 out of 5, calling it "high on classical base" and saying half of the compositions were situational and narrative-based that can "be expected to make a good impression on screen"
The Indian Express also gave it a 3.5 out of 5, noting its distinct sound and its "balance between restraint and exuberance"

Firstpost gave a highly positive review, praising the "elegantly arranged and opulently orchestrated" songs and writing, "exhilarating soundtrack ... recreates an era gone-by through sounds that are authentic ... yet operatic, steeped in the classical ethos, yet contemporary"
The soundtrack album was well received by music critics, who praised the soulful compositions and called them "melodious and fresh".[72]

Bajirao Mastani was one of the most anticipated releases of 2015.
Everything was done in secrecy during production to avoid leaks.
On 15 July 2015, producers Eros International shared the first images of the three characters and a teaser poster of the film before releasing the three-minute teaser trailer.
The three-minute teaser trailer was released on 16 July 2015.
With only one line of dialogue, the three-minute teaser trailer was released on 16 July 2015.
The three-minute teaser trailer, with only one line of dialogue, was deemed 'grand' and 'epic'.
News18 called the teaser 'regal, grand and breathtaking'.
The teaser had all the signature Bhansali elements such as 'the big sets'.

News18 called the teaser 'regal, grand and breathtaking' and wrote that it had all the signature Bhansali elements such as 'the big sets', 'larger than life characters', 'lots of colours' and a 'tragic love story in the midst of all this grandeur'.
Characters posters of the three characters were also unveiled in early November 2015.
The trailer was released on 20 November 2015 and was also well received.
As a part of the promotions for the film, a multi-episode animated series based on Bajirao's life was released digitally in November 2015.
The graphic web series narrates the tales of Bajirao's heroism and his relationship with his two wives.
Following the release of the web series, a video game featuring animated avatars of Bajirao and his wives was released in December 2015.
A multi-city promotional event for the film saw visits by Singh and Padukone to several cities in India.
During the promotions, Priyanka Chopra was unable to participate due to her involvement in the American television series Quantico.
To promote the film, Priyanka Chopra held a press conference for the media in New York City.

node_2: most expensive hindi film ever made
edge: Bajirao Mastani is a Hindi film that cost approximately ₹125 crore to make, making it one of the most expensive films in Indian cinema history.
The total budget for the production and marketing of Bajirao Mastani was approximately ₹145 crore.
Before its release, Bajirao Mastani had already recovered almost all of its production costs through the sale of satellite, music, and overseas rights.
Bajirao Mastani was initially scheduled for release on 18 December 2015, but faced a release date clash with another major Bollywood film.
Due to the release date clash, Bajirao Mastani had to share screens with the competing film in a 40:60 ratio.
Upon release, Bajirao Mastani received widespread critical acclaim from the film industry and critics.

The DVD and Blu-ray versions of Bajirao Mastani were released in all regions on 18 March 2016, and included documentaries about the film's making, sets, costumes, music, movie images, and deleted scenes.
The film was also released digitally on platforms such as iTunes.
Bajirao Mastani is also available for streaming on the Eros Now platform.
The film had its world television premiere on 23 April 2016 on the Colors TV network.

The film maintained its strong box office run on weekdays.
Bajirao Mastani earned ₹84.36 crore nett in the first week at the domestic box office,
while the first-week worldwide collections were over ₹160 crore.
Revenues grew nearly 20% on its second Friday, earning ₹12.5 crore nett.
The film earned over ₹31.1 crore in its second weekend and collected a further ₹5.25 crore on the second Monday for an eleven-day domestic total of ₹141 crore nett.
In the second week, the film earned approximately ₹55.2 crore.
The film registered the fourth-highest third-week collections of all time, earning a ₹27 crore.
After its fourth week collection of ₹7 crore,
the film's domestic earnings stood at ₹175 crore nett.

The accuracy of Rau, which is a novel, has long been questioned.
Bhansali consulted historian Ninad Bedekar, who is regarded as an authority on the Peshwas.
There has been controversy over Mastani's true lineage;
Two accounts of Mastani exist – one which says she was a tawaif and Bajirao's mistress or concubine,
and another that is depicted in the film.
has not been covered much by
represents how Bajirao was in his personal life
Because of this lack of information, Bhansali took liberties with historical facts for cinematic effects. The film's credits state it does not claim to be historically accurate.
The dance sequences in the film have been widely seen as 'fictional' and 'out of place' in historical context.
A chief minister such as Bajirao would never dance in public.
The 'Pinga' dance sequence between Kashibai and Mastani has been deemed 'inappropriate' for women of that era.
Romantic relationship between Bajirao and Mastani as portrayed in the film. In reality, they did not die at the same time and Mastani was never chained during her death.
Lived together after the death of Mastani as portrayed in the film. In reality, Kashibai raised Mastani's son as her own.
Some historians have said that Kashibai, a woman of stature, should not have danced in public due to an undisclosed type of arthritis.
Some historians claimed both women met only once, while others said they never met at all.
Put Mastani under house arrest while Bajirao was on military campaign as portrayed in the film. In reality, this happened before his death.
Some historians claimed that Mastani died from shock or committed suicide, while others have not provided a clear explanation for her death.
Present at Bajirao's last rites as portrayed in the film. In reality, they both were present during this time.
Raised Mastani's son as her own after her death as portrayed in the film. In reality, this happened.
Portrayed playing a mandola, an instrument that originated in Europe during the 19th century.
